description.text: This design requires supports while printing. It takes a few hours to remove all the supports with pliers, but the results are definitely worth it!
A scaled down version of ZeeMan's Read Keychain.
Printed with a MakerBot Replicator. Printed raftless with the platform at 110 and the extruder at 230.

I bought this $7 60x jeweler's loupe on Amazon some time ago, and wanted to take iPhone photos through it. I also didn't want to have to remove my phone from its case every time I wanted to use it. This mount holds the loupe in position while being easy to put on and take off. (It turns out the field of view is pretty limited, but you can get an idea of the resulting photos from the images above of Roosevelt's face on a dime and some tweezer tips. Customizable so you can adapt it to your own needs/phone/case. Updated: lens positioning fudge factors were reversed, some default dimensions were adjusted. If you do not need to customize this, I suggest checking out my two part version, which requires gluing but puts the smooth bottom surfaces on the phone/case contact side, to prevent scuffing your case.
The supplied STL is for an iPhone 5s with an Apple leather case and the loupe linked in the description. Other loupes/phones/cases can be made to work with some testing if you have calipers.

description.text:
I decided to design new bed leveling knobs from scratch after yesterday printing a bunch and finding out that none of them fit the far adjustment knob properly. This final design was my 8th iteration and I printed 6 prints before deciding on what fit perfectly, and then adjusted for the maximum size that would fit - on the back adjustment knob. A fair amount of work went into this design, even though it's pretty basic - so I hope you get some use out of it!

This ended up being more complicated than I first thought however the final print works perfectly and I will be replacing all 3 of my adjustment knobs with this design!

Note: Flip the design so that you print it with the flat cutout on the bottom. Then to attach it to the stock knobs, just remove the knob entirely and slot it into the print.

title: Printed Solid Lulzbot Mini Enclosure Bracket for LCD

description.text: If you have the Lulzbot Mini Enclosure by Printed Solid and have the new LCD control panel from Lulzbot then this new right bracket will allow you to mount the LCD and the enclosure together. Remove the existing bracket and replace it with this one. Using the same M3-40 bolt it will go through the bracket and through the frame of the printer and then thread into the LCD mount bracket. Go slow and be careful. Unfortunately you will be going through two threads, the one on the frame and the one on the LCD mount. So go slow and if it takes force to turn the screw you might be double threading the LCD bracket or pushing the heat insert out of the LCD bracket. You will need to remove The stiffener on the top of the enclosure part "H"

title: Glass Bed Holders for Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
These parts hold a 213x200mm glass build plate on my Duplicator i3. I designed them to flex a little, so that they will hold the plate snugly even as the aluminum of the heated bed slightly expands and contracts.

To install, remove the thumb nuts used to level the bed. Then, loosen the screws in the four corners of the bed, allowing for a few millimeters of vertical movement. Slip on the plate holders, with the broad sides facing the front and back of the printer. Finally, tighten the screws again, put the thumb nuts back on, and press your glass plate in.

author: Pineapplecake

title: Printed Solid Lulzbot Mini LCD Case

description.text: Do you have the Lulzbot Mini LCD upgrade? Do you not like the idea of mounting it over the front of the printer covering up the view inside or getting in the way of your enclosure? Well here is the solution for you. This allows you to mount the LCD over the control box to the left and out of the way of the enclosure entirely. It mounts using 2 M3-10 or M3-12 nuts and bolts through existing holes already in the printer. There are two ways to route the ribbon cables. The first is through the top of the electronics enclosure or the better way is out the window and into the case. Then use 3 M3-20 or M3-25 bolts to attach the back to existing holes on the LCD. It covers the wires on the back and gives you plenty of room to hide the extra cable length. Far easier to install and less parts used compared to mounting it on the front right of the printer. If you have the enclosure you will need to remove the short side panel on the left of the printer. Don't worry, you will still have enough enclosure to keep the space nice and toasty.

title: Retro Rubber Band Powered Rocket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I have had this rubber band launched rocket for as long as I can remember... at least 35 years. Unlike today's toys, aside from the occasional rubber band replacements, this thing has stood the test of time! I thought I would share this piece of nostalgia with all of you.

You can, of course, print your rocket in whatever color scheme you like, but the original was molded in red and white, as shown in the illustrations. The completed rocket is 245mm tall, including the grip. The main body itself is 195mm tall. What with the additions I've added to my Tevo Tarantula, I only have 170mm available on the Z axis. For this reason, I have provided two versions of the main rocket body. I highly suggest that you use the _1piece model if at all possible. If, like me, though, you can't, you can print the _upper and _lower halves and glue them together.

ADDITIONAL PARTS NEEDED
You will need a few non-printed items to finish your model:

  • small snap swivel (the type used for fishing)
  • small parachute - if you don't have a commercial parachute, this is an excellent tutorial on making one from a plastic bag
  • cotton string
  • rubber band, large
  • rubber band, medium

I have no idea why, in the photo, the printed model looks bigger than the (red/white) original. They are both the exact same size...

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

All pieces should be printed in the orientation presented in the STL files with [Supports Everywhere] enabled. The only exception to the need for support is the launcher and the baydoor_fin. Furthermore, due to their small footprint, you should use a fairly large [Brim] - 7mm or so - for the grip and the stabilizer_fin. I recommend 100% infill, just for strength. I tried slicing with less infills and, honestly, the added amount of filament required and the additional time needed was not significantly different enough to warrant using anything less than 100%. I printed with a layer height of 0.2mm, but I don't think that it too critical.

**ASSEMBLING THE ROCKET**

Assembly is pretty straight forward as you can see from the assembly diagrams.

  1. Hook the holes in the grip over the pins in the ejector, making sure that the hook is on top.
  2. Slide a rubber band over the ejector so that it is around the rear section. Pull the rubber band up and loop it around the hook on the grip, running the rubber band through the notch of the ejector. This will pull the ejector up at a 90° angle. Make sure that the rubber band is not too tight or the door won't stay closed during the rocket's ascent.
  3. Keeping the ejector/grip assembly straight, slide both pieces into the body from the rear. Once in the body, the ejector will snap back to a 90° angle. Don't worry about that right now.
  4. Slide the stabilizer fin into the slot in the rear - narrow end forward and two lines on top - making sure that it goes through the grip and out the slot on the other side. You will need to make sure that once the fin is through, you have one one of the raised lines on top of the fin on either side of the body. This is what keeps the fin in place.
  5. Glue the nose cone to the front of the rocket.
  6. Push the bay door fin down on to it's mount on the bay door - narrow end forward. There is a small bump on either side of the mount that will keep the fin in place. You can glue this fin on for added security, if you'd like.
  7. Insert the pins on the inner font of the bay door into their associated holes in the main body, being careful as you spread the legs so as not to break them.
  8. Tie a 5 or 6 inch long piece of cotton string to the bay door mount where indicated in the diagram.
  9. Attach a parachute, via a snap swivel, to the ejector where indicated on the diagram.
  10. Lightly fold and wrap the parachute using standard rocketry procedures and place it in the front section of the ejector. I have included a PDF explaining how to pack the chute if you need it.
  11. Press the ejector / parachute down into the rocket and close the bay door. Take the string that you tied around the mount earlier and bring it back past the top tail fin. For storage, to keep the bay door closed, simply wrap the string around the grip and tie it off.
**PREPARING THE LAUNCHER**
  1. To prepare the launcher, you will need to cut your large rubber band so that you have one long piece.
  2. Tie a knot in one end of the rubber band and slip the other end through one of the bottom holes on the launcher.
  3. Thread the loose end of the band back through the top hole on the same side.
  4. Pull the loose end through the top hole on the other side and back through the last bottom hole.
  5. Tie a knot in the loose end of the rubber band.
  6. Finally, pull the large loop so that the knot are firmly up against the plastic.
**LAUNCHING YOUR ROCKET**

Now you are all set for the fun part! With your parachute loaded, and the bay door closed, make sure the string is hanging loosely. Pull the free end of the string back past the top fin and hold it against the side of the grip - thumb on one side and forefinger on the other. Loop the hook at the front of the rocket on the rubber band on the launcher. Holding the grip in one hand and the launcher in the other, pull back and aim upwards. Let go of the grip and watch your rocket soar upwards.

**HOW IT WORKS**

The wind resistance against the bay door will keep the door closed as the rocket soars upwards. As the rocket slows, the wind resistance forcing down on the door lessens. As soon as the rubber band inside is able to overcome the force of the air rushing past the fin, the ejector will spring outwards, opening the bay door and ejecting to parachute. As the rocket begins to fall, the air will grab the parachute and pop it open, allowing your rocket to gradually, and safely, drift back down to earth.

HAPPY FLIGHTS

description.text: Put this GoPro mount on a MOLLE plate carrier. GoPro mount will have to be attached via adhesive mount.

From my build page-

Having designed and released a pile of different Pan and Tilt units I decided to try and make something a little different. I came up with a list of simple design goals that were based on requests and experiences with other PnT's. The list then, in (my) order of importance is:

*Lighter and Faster than my HD Pan and tilt which is around 100g

  • New weight is ~80g with the components shown here

*Is smooth and precise with excellent centering

  • With a new, fully programmable digital Hitec HS-5245MG servo, it is extremely smooth and centers beautifully

*Is more aerodynamic

  • Now with both servos mounted below the deck, it is very aerodynamic

*Can be made from off-the-shelf components

  • All but one component is made from standard off-the-shelf parts (see text)

*Rotates 360° or more

  • Rotation can be programmed from 236° to 398°

*Tilts down 50 degrees or more

  • Tilts down 42° (see text)

Mechanical Specifications-
-Total weight with all hardware shown - 80 grams
-Pan rotaion - 236 - 398 degrees
-Tilt range - 0-42 degrees (down)

For more information, pictures and build specs, please see my Wiki here:
http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Geared_Aerodynamic_Pan_and_Tilt

comments.text: There is no drawback. If you read the build page you would see that one of my design goals was to make everything needed out of simple off-the-shelf parts. This means easy to build and as little specialized work as possible. Certainly if you want more accuracy you can pay for it but you will not see any difference in the camera as the change in tilt is 0.0039 degrees per degree of rotation. description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

I was the Founder of the Infamous Call of Duty Clan from about 10 years back. Once I purchased my 3D Printer, I thought it would be frikken awesome to have a set of 3D Maps from COD 1 & 2 to mosaic on my wall. I spent thousands of hours in those worlds and got quite connected to them...

print_settings.Notes:: You will probably need to use PETG in order to get the adjustable version of the DisClasp to work properly. Trust me I tried MANY iterations of the design and print settings before I got everything tuned in just right. I found that PLA and ABS were too brittle and would break every time I pushed the two pins into place in the back piece. PETG is a lot more pliable so it will accept them without breaking, yet still be strong enough to securely clip in your disc!

description.text:
It struck me one day that it was frustratingly impossible to enjoy two of my favorite activities simultaneously: disc golfing and drinking a nice cold beer.

Enter the DisClasp. A fully-adjustable clip that lets you carry ANY disc golfing disc on your belt and either store or access using only one hand! Never again be without your favorite beverage while playing a casual round. My original intent behind this invention was to bring the product to market & sell them at sporting goods stores, but sadly after months of intense legwork trying to get the business off of the ground the future didn't look very good for the project.

Now I am releasing my designs to the public so that anyone with a 3D printer can try them out! They do require a few small hardware items so I suggest that if you are going to make some you make them in batches and give them to your friends so you don't have to pay $5 to ship 2 pins that cost 11 cents..... :'(

I have a bunch of them sitting around still also so if you think they are cool and don't want to make them yourself check them out at my website:

https://www.walkernelson.net/disclasp-hub/

You can buy them there and also view pictures and instructions (one instructional gif... they are pretty self explanatory).

Printer:

HomeBrew i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

65%

Notes:

You will probably need to use PETG in order to get the adjustable version of the DisClasp to work properly. Trust me I tried MANY iterations of the design and print settings before I got everything tuned in just right. I found that PLA and ABS were too brittle and would break every time I pushed the two pins into place in the back piece. PETG is a lot more pliable so it will accept them without breaking, yet still be strong enough to securely clip in your disc!

Putting it all together

You can make the non-adjustable version of the disclasp without any extra parts or post-processing, but if you want to make the deluxe version you will need to buy a few parts and assemble it.

~ M3 Locknut. I got mine from McMaster Carr but I'm sure you can find one at your local
hardware store

~ M3 x 16 Socket Cap Screw. I also got these from McMaster but again, Ace hardware is
your friend

~ 0.125" x 0.675" (11/16)" Steel Pins. You will need two of these. I got them from a specialty
website in a big batch. I will work on getting a link to the exact item at a better price but
3/4" long ones will probably work. You can get those here:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B001OBPJMI/ref=biss_dp_t_buying_options

~ 2.5mm allen key. Get this at a hardware store if you don't have one.

More updates on this & links to parts soon

Step 1: Place Pins

Once you have everything assembly is pretty easy. Take the back piece (you will clip this onto your belt/pants) and put it so the holes face up. Tap the pins in LIGHTLY with a hammer. Try to keep them straight.

Pins in place Step 2: Place Screw

Next put the M3 Screw in place.

Sorry about the sideways angle... Step 3: Nut in Place

Now get the M3 Nut and put it into the hole in the other side of the DisClasp. Make sure the locking part faces away from the open part of the hole. You will need to get the nut to go in so that one corner of the nut faces directly up into the air like in the picture shown, otherwise it won't work. This can be tricky and should be pretty tight so have patience.... It helps to use pliers so you can push down on the angled sides of the nut well in their correct orientation.

Nut in Place. Good job this is hard! Step 4: Slap it Together & Enjoy

Now just slide the pins into the holes on the front part and tighten everything up with your allen key!

title: Muffin Liner Press
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This muffin liner press is designed to rapidly make muffin/cupcake liners for generic muffin/cupcake trays. The model needs to be printed twice in order to make the press.

You can make your own liners by cutting parchment paper in 6 x 6 inches squares, sandwiching one square between the two parts of the press, and then pressing the two parts together firmly. For stronger folds, you can experiment with a gentle twisting motion while pressing the two parts together.

The end result is a quickly repeatable liner with pointy corners sticking out higher than the muffin top, which gives each muffin a very stylish, yet homemade, look.

If you are a serious baker, consider printing this model 13 times. Then, you can stack and store them with 12 parchment paper squares sandwiched in between so that you have enough liners pre-made for your next batch of muffins.

Printer:

Flashforge Inventor

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

25%

Unlike some of my other prints, this one went very smoothly. I designed three versions of this muffin liner press starting by measuring the dimensions of one muffin hole in a muffin tray. I sketched two circles on two separate planes, created a loft between the circles to get the overall shape, and then created a shell of a couple mm thickness. At the time, my printer software did not offer the option to create a raft, skirt, or brim so I initially had a much wider circular base of 0.2mm thickness designed in to serve as a skirt. This was required because the printer had a tendency to knock down the model during the printing of the upper layers.

title: Anet A8 E3D Direct X-Carriage w/ Probe (46mm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I am giving credit to IsmaelPR1 for his a8 e3d direct mount design, which I used as inspiration for my x carriage design. His original design is unfortunately meant for 45mm rod spacing (older a8's), lacked a decent z probe mount solution (other remixes with probes were off mark IMHO), and had some minor design issues (mainly the X-belt hole fit, and cooling flow arrangement). I also wanted to add a few creature comforts to complete the bill; so I got out my calipers and freecad, and started from scratch for a complete redraw.

This carriage fits newer A8's with 46mm rod spacing. I added a mount for a 12mm threaded probe with 0 y offset, and 33mm x offset. There is also a teardrop shape hole above the probe mount to give clearance for larger probes (my clone 4mm induction probe is LOOOONG and needs that room for the wires). I also redesigned the right side structure to improve air flow (the original directed most of the air down toward the part). I added a strain relief for the wires, a slotted hole to further secure the extruder motor, and a tons of fillets to make it more robust. I added a small chamfer on the top of the hotend mounting "ring". This small feature is important to keep the extruder locked in the proper position (prusa i3 has it too). I also increased the distance between the top bearings to 18mm. No reason not to do this as it doesn't reduce build volume, and it greatly reduces carriage rocking. Last but not least, I added up arrows to the hotend and probe straps. Hopefully they will never get installed upside down this way. ;)

I have this thing printed in abs, 60% bicubic infill, 1mm walls, and board only supports. The strain relief part unfortunately requires support. I chose a 40mm hotend fan duct by ChPech for my BB fan, a Mistral 2.1 part blower duct by Leo_N, and an X-belt clip by Simhopp for my printed accessories. I feel those parts are very well engineered, but other options will likely also fit. Everything fits like a glove, and this thing has been installed and printing for several days with zero issues. Enjoy!

[edit: Anticipating questions about the path from extruder wheel to the hotend... It uses an e3d clone with a bowden style heatsink, with the bowden tube fitting removed. The stock A8 throat is inverted so the wider teflon lined end goes down. To assemble first install the e3d, then slide the nut on top of the e3d. Then cut new teflon tube (about 4" long) just the right length so that the motor sits down completely on the top plate without having to squish hard on the tube, and not being too short so it can move with retraction (have your throat depth at the motor adjusted about where you want it before you trim the tube). Slide this tube in to the inverted stock throat, put the motor/top-throat/tube down the hole into the e3d, and tighten the nut. You may have to use some teflon tape, threadlock compound, or pliers on the throat/motor threads as tightening the nut without may result in pulling the throat up into the extruder wheel (a flex adapter helps prevent this). Optionally, you can use the slotted hole to further secure the motor with an M4 screw. I omitted this myself so I could rotate the motor CG closer to the x-bars.]

description.text:
This will be re-uploaded to another site once a suitible site is found. I do not believe that I, or the original author (in the case of my derived works) appreciates giving up all rights to own our own designs. Once A suitible location is found, or a temporary one is located, A note will be posted here. Have fun! Download link: http://randmsystems.com/Media/printer/catapult_accessories_b.stl These are accessories and add-ons to the Seej Catapult. In the combined file, half are from other people, sources attributed. The accessories are as follows:
Standing Legs Attachment - As anyone who's printed the catapult notices, the arm hits the ground and may throw aim off a bit. These are just printed out and snapped on the bottom to give it a little bit more height. They can be removed (front or back) to adjust aim a little. Standard Arm: I like to print this as part of the kit, along with another thing which will be posted later. It just feels incomplete without this. Cup-arm: Wauter made this rather nice cup, and I like it as part of the accessory kit I use. Horizontal-Arm: While play-testing Seej, a few of players insisted on trying to use the standard arm to launch a penny sideways, for more surface area. This was created as an answer to that. Two pennies can be fitted into it's shaped-bucket. Delux Tripple-Arm: Mattbstrong made this one as part of a delux catapult. While the arm is a bit tight for pennies (Does a good job with dimes), it's too cool to exclude.

The round-bucket cup is from the Seej Catapult Mod by Wauter at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24074 The 3-penny launcher is from the SEEJ Deluxe Penny Catapult by Mattbstrong at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27775 The single-launcher is from the stock Seej. The standing legs are original. The dual-penny horizontal penny launcher is original (Although was by request)

The shower head holder in my bathroom broke and the fix that was purchase sucked, so I set out to design my own. I wanted it to be strong, adjustable and simple to print. I think I may have succeeded. This is a fairly easy and quick print with no need for supports if you opt for the glue version. I have also included a version that doesn't need to be glued together but would require a little support and may not be as strong.

For the glued version, print a head mount, arm end, base, and screw. Everything should fit together fairly easily.

If you opt for the glue-less one, sub out the head mount and arm end for the arm end hand head mount 1pc. That probably seemed obvious. This version will need supports for the overhang.

Just an FYI, I haven't actually printed the one piece head holder so good luck with that.

Always trying to find something to cut the filament with?

Here's a robust filament cutter you can mount on your 3D printer (I use a Tronxy P802M). Feel free to modify the base to fit your printer.

Uses part of a standard 3/4" box cutter blade. No need to be precise, there's plenty of room to fit the blade (mine never snaps of clean). A couple of pen springs, two 20mm M3 and one 10mm M3 screw is all that's needed (and we all have lots of those don't we).

Blade is angled so a nice clean cut will help with feeding the filament into the extruder.
Once assembled, adjust the blade height with the bottom 20mm screws. Blade should align with the bottom of the snipping hole.
Happy snipping!

description.text:
I used bdring's extruder lever in my QUBD extruder for quite a while with mostly good results. I found however that it would catch on the raised area of the stepper motor and would not allow the bearing to sit completely tight against the MK7 drive gear that I use. With some filaments that ran a little thin, this led to slipping and clogging.

I also found that if I was using flexible filament, the space between the lever and the drive gear allowed the filament to get at an angle which led to it buckling and winding up all around the spaces in there.

This was my experience, I'm sure that others had different results. I decided to modify the lever to see if I could get better results. I expanded the curved opening on the back side more to make sure that it clears the raised section on my stepper motor. This allows the bearing to sit against the MK7 drive gear which has stopped me from having any slipping or clogging. I also stretched the channel section down to where it almost meets the drive gear which keeps the filament aligned straight into the drive gear. This has allowed me to run flexible filament without it buckling and winding into the extruder.

description.text:
The episode in [ENGLISH]: http://www.mojoptix.com/?p=178
L'episode en [FRANCAIS]: tres bientot !
Note: To see more inventions and contraptions (like this one ), suscribe to Mojoptix on Youtube !
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Tadam !
A fully working caliper that uses a Moire pattern to reach a precision better than 0.05 mm. The accuracy should be better than 0.5mm.

No batteries, no electronics, no gears... It's just a couple of images sliding one on top of the other. The two images have been mathematically designed to display a Moire pattern shaped like an "indicator triangle": the tip of the triangle will indicate the sub-millimeter measurement.

How to use this caliper

Simply read the cm and mm on the main scale, and then the sub-millimeter value on the Moire scale.

A couple of short clips

Check out this short video to see it in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W-Au9vlV2nQ
This short video might help visualize a bit the Assembly (refer to the section "Post-Printing" below for more details): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-yDPLzs7wKM

Notes:

3D printing

I would recommend to print the 3D parts in the orientation the STL files are already in:
they have a chamfer at the bottom to reduce the "elephant foot" effect, and the crenellated patterns (on the "boot") or the gaps (on the "shoe" and "hook") should completely(-ish) eliminate any warping.
And if you 3D print on a glass platform, this should also give you flat and shinny surfaces at just the right places.
PLA is maybe preferable to ABS for this object: it less susceptible to warping and is a bit less flexible.

2D printing

The "Top_image_Transparency.png" image must be printed on a transparency (the same kind you would use on an overhead projector). And it would be best to print the "Bottom_image_PhotoPaper.png" image on a thick photographic paper (120g/m2 or heavier).
You'll need to print them with a resolution of 600 DPI (or better)

The most important thing is to both images with the exact same printer settings, at the exact same place on the page (for example: centered), and with the same orientation !

Also make sure that the software you are using to print the image does not rescale them. The free software Irfanview does work nicely for this purpose.

Note 1: The Mojoptix episode (see link at the top) has also a video of a full build.
Note 2: Use slow-drying glue ! Aligning optical components is not something you want to rush.

Aligning and gluing the Transparent image

Apply some glue on the tiny trench on the underside of the Frame, then place it on the Transparent image. Use the two outer lines (with all the tick marks) to carefully center the Transparent image inside the opening of the Frame.
Once the glue is dry, you can slide the Frame inside the Boot component.

Aligning and gluing the Bottom image

Apply some glue on the backside of the Bottom image paper, then slide it in place inside the Boot component, just below the Transparent image. The Bottom image is a bit longer than the Boot, so you can bend the outer edges to help you move it around. The goal is to align perfectly the axis of the dotted line on the Bottom image with the axis of the dotted line on the Transparent image.

Gluing the Shoe

Set the Caliper to 0.00mm. Position the Shoe component in place: the flat surfaces of the caliper jaws should be perfectly in contact. Then apply a generous amount of glue on the top side of the Shoe, to glue it to the Frame.

Gluing the Hook

Set the Caliper again to 0.00mm. Apply some glue on the leg of the Hook component and position it on the Boot component. Position the Hook such that the flat underside of the Hook's hook is levelled with the flat topside of the protusion from the Frame.

[ENGLISH]
An episode on Mojoptix describes this invention in great details: http://www.mojoptix.com/?p=178

Although the bracing on the Tronxy P802M is quite good, this makes it even better.

Simple but effective design using 4 M3 10mm screws and 8mm screw rod. Go to your local hardware store and buy some 8mm rod (cost me $2.50 for a 60cm rod).

Cut each rod to 26.5cm and screw all the way into the bottom section (best to do this when plastic is still warm). Hold bottom rod in place with M3 screw. Screw in top section but not all the way. Mount bottom section using one of the already used M3 20mm screws. Rotate top brace until it fits just under the horizontal part of the top part of the frame (where the display is located). Mount the top section with the two already used M3 20mm screws. Do the other side and you're done.

Please let me know when you make one and post a photo.

This is a gravity actuated grappling claw designed to be carried by a drone to recover small objects from rooftops or other places that are hard to get to.

To assemble this claw you will need
20pcs M3 X 12mm machine screws
1pc M3 X ~25mm machine screw
21pcs M3 lock nuts
1pc M3 washer (to prevent screw from pulling through the mount plate)
some rope (paracord works well)

Assemble according to what is seen in the photos. One not-so-obvious point about assembly is that the claw will perform much better if the outer strut is assembled with the pointy end facing up to prevent the tines from travelling past the midline (which makes it much harder for the claw to open around the object you are trying to pick up).

Total weight when printed in ABS at 4 perimeters, 4 top layers, and 4 bottom layers, including all hardware, is 72g.

This should probably go without saying but if you use this with your drone, you do so at your own risk. You are not allowed to use this object if you're going to come after me if you crash your drone while playing with it, or if you hurt somebody in the process. This hook is also a lot of fun to use without a drone. Works surprisingly well for what it is. Quick demo here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kvdDpFkNKz4

title: Decade resistance box for smaller thumbwheels/pushwheels

description.text:
Figured I'd try DesignSpark out to see how it treated me.

Onto the project.
The thumbwheels I got were a bit smaller than any others I had seen here so I designed a new box. My thumbwheels are 8.00mm x 16.10mm (Not including flange. I printed the first layer slow (15mm/sec) just so the detail of the raised letters came out OK. No supports needed. I printed at .22 layer height but anything will work. There are many thumbwheels out there and the sizes vary greatly. Make sure you get the right size.

  • Use 2.5mm or 3mm (Tighter fit and recommended) x 6-8mm (Or longer) screws.
  • I used banana jacks w/ flats to clock the jacks so you may need to slightly open up the box if your jacks are perfectly round or just force i through :).

title: Monoprice Mini Delta 127 mm Glass Bed Holder

description.text:
This bed holder allows a 127mm glass bed to be held on the aluminum bed of the Monoprice Mini Delta .

This is complicated by the fact that the bed needs to move up and down for the auto leveling to function. The black clips that swing into place to hold the bed down have a camming effect as they rotate, so I start by placing two of these bed holders onto the printer with their clips in position, and set the glass bed into them . the third holder is placed, and its clip is rotated to just tighten the glass in position, but still allowing it to move up and down. Its easier than it sounds.

The larger the file number , the tighter the fit on the bed, in case your printer is slightly different. i also included the .skb if you wish to modify it. 6127 is the tightest one so far. I'll see how that works once I print out 3 of them

You can use some 3m painters tape to hold them to the bed to avoid them poping out

plate fixer for 2mm polycarbonate

this is a print in place item. this has a ratchet mechanism to keep roller from unwinding.
i made supports to hold the roller from lifting during print (as happened to me). you need be careful removing these and regular supports to ensure clean operation. place supports in slots for tube in front. and place supports under roller, near the supports i made. take a razor and carefully cut between knob and frame to help loosen supports there. the end opposite the knob must be squeezed to push out the roller, so you can clean in the area of the frame where the ratchet action happens. clean the knob in the area around around the ratchet area to ensure clean operation.
also to print, rotate the model to place it flat on the supports i made.
i included a stp file in case you want to modify it to your liking.
i included a gcode file with supports to see how i did it.
i made the rod and frame separate in case you want to print them alone. which will made cleaning them easier.

title: Anet A8 right side brace / stiffener Version 2

description.text:
Oscar's "Anet A8 right side brace / stiffener" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2077336 did not fit with my Anet A8 from Gearbest.
As mentioned on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2077336 there seem to be several versions of Anet A8.
I had to make several adjustments:

Hole "1" had to be moved up
Hole "1" and "2" are enlarged to 4mm to allow more room.
Recess "3" has been enlarged
Holes "4" were shifted slightly to the right.
The thickness of the front "5" was reduced from 8mm to 6mm (otherwise the movement of the X axis to the right was not possible).

The holes "1" and "2" have a distance of about 91.6mm for my part and 90mm for the part of "Oscar". Maybe this can help if the part of me or the part of "Oscar" fits.

If oriented with 4 tabs "up" , no supports are needed.

author: javy1389

description.text:
I just wanted to show you my DIY Rack for my 3d Printer and my 2d Printer.

It is build around 4040 aluminium profiles, which i ordered from ebay. For this exact build you will need
4x 140 cm
and 20x 40 cm (i actually measured the width in height of every component to be implemented and picked the tightest fit (there is like 1.5 cm of space left and right of the printer).
Additionally i used "hobby glass" (i hate this stuff) and 3 mm high density fiberboard.

I do not recommend to fix the profiles only with the 3d printed parts, because it is a little bit shaky. I bought additional 10 professional corners to stabilize it.
The screws i used were M3x16mm and i needed almost 500 of them - it was a pain.

In case you are wondering where all the electronics are, they are in the middle compartment behind the controlpanel.

Maybe you find an inspiration out of my work.

Surroundings temperature probe: https://www.banggood.com/12V-40110C-Auto-LED-Digital-Thermometer-Meter-Probe-p-994934.html

https://www.banggood.com/30cm-USB-20-B-Male-to-USB-B-Female-Socket-Printer-Panel-Mount-Cable-p-923586.html

So I work as an experimental physicist. My area of expertise is reasearch with synchrotron radiation. So basicly what we do, is to prepare our experiment in our labs and then we bring them with a big truck to the research facility. For easy transportation the experiments are mounted on custom frames made out of these aluminium profiles.

Once i worked with them i absolutley fell in love with the simplicity and designed the rack like i would design a frame for an experiment.

description.text:
After shock of this part price i have decided to try to make my own with a 3D printer. It needs a bit of skill, but now the magazine works properly even with printed spring. Unfortunately this kind of spring does not allow you to fill mag with more than three rounds.

If you can use steel spring, it would be better.

All modifications are allowed, but please do not use this model for commercial purposes. I would like to fight high prices of these parts by printing them for free (or for price of used filament).

Main body, follower and bottom part should be rotated 90° in x axis before slicing. There should be some support material for the follower too.

Bottom plate and gluing

I have filled space in shape of spade with kyanoacrylate glue and later I have brushed whole bottom to a high glossy surface.

I recommend to glue bottom and main body together after completing the magazine. But first be sure, your spring works properly. Do not glue the follower, but you may grease it for better movement inside of magazine.

print_settings.Notes:: Depending on the strength of your magnet you may want relatively high infill to keep the bracket from deforming over time. However, correctly mounted there should be little stress on the bracket most of the time.

description.text:
Our garden door would open itself a few centimetres if not locked from one side or another. This causes draught, escaping dogs and all kinds of unwanted by-products when we are just in the garden for a bit and don't want to lock the door from the outside.

This bracket keeps the door closed but stille easily pushed open. It uses flat round 20mm diameter neodynium magnet with a hole in the middle. One os affixed to the door and another glued to this bracket. The door is closed and the bracket screwed into place while held in the correct position by the locked door.

The magnet in the bracket is held by 1mm of plastic so that the two magnets don't slam together. If your magnets are too weak, you might want to reduce that distance.

Shetchup source included.

UPDATE: Added version 2 which is a bit smaller on one side and has a lid to cover the mechanics. Version 2 Sketchup file includes the version 1 design.

Notes:

Depending on the strength of your magnet you may want relatively high infill to keep the bracket from deforming over time. However, correctly mounted there should be little stress on the bracket most of the time.
Put a bit of glue in the magnet hole of the bracket, put in the magnet and keep it in place by resting the other magnet on the other side like it is supposed to be when the door is closed.

author: xkremator

title: Intuitive Difficulty RPG/Game Dice (D7 on D20)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Intuitive Difficulty Dice

Each time you need to roll "one more than before", it becomes more difficult by the same factor (140%), approximately.

Great for sensible difficulty increases in RPGs and Wargames that use a lot of Die Modifiers (+/- DMs)

Can be used in game design to eliminate complicated rules, extra tables, and mental arithmetics.

Includes FreeCAD source files in case you'd like to modify the design.

Distribution

The Intuitive Difficulty Dice feature the following distribution:

  • 1: 7x
  • 2: 4x
  • 3: 3x
  • 4: 2x
  • 5: 2x
  • 6: 1x
  • 7: 1x

The chances of achieving a certain number or higher are:

  • 1: 100% :-)
  • 2: 70%
  • 3: 45%
  • 4: 25%
  • 5: 15%
  • 6: 10%
  • 7: 5x

The chances of success for each increase of +1 are reduced to the following percentage of the unmodified chances:

1 + 1: 70%
2 + 1: 71%
3 + 1: 70%
4 + 1: 60%
5 + 1: 67%
6 + 1: 50%

So the die is not perfect, due to only having a finite number of faces, but I think it's pretty good :-)

History

I came up with this die out of frustration with convention die roll modification systems back in the late 1980s, calling it the "logarithmic die". Attempts to build such a die by modifying existing dies resulted in ugly, stickered, poorly-rolling creations so that I gave up on the concept.

My hopes that someone else would have the same idea and come up with a nice mass-produced die of this type unfortunately never materialized.

With the advent 3D printing, it suddenly became easy to have good-looking and accurate dice printed, so I designed these dice in FreeCAD. Yay!

Fairness

Obviously, the more accurate the print, the better the chances that the die rolls are distributed truly randomly. I had my dice printed by a service provider using a laser-sintering process that gave quite satisfactory accuracy.

I measured the dimensions with a micrometer screw, and the distance between each two opposite faces varied between 18.16 mm and 18.37 mm in the extremes, which I'm quite happy with.

The weight distribution of the dice is even in spite of the use of "pips" (holes) to indicate the values, as the diameter and depth of the holes is varied to ensure that the total volume of the pips is the same on each side.

author: Antalpromille

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Owners of an original Atari 7800 will know all too well that certain unusually shaped 2600 cartridges will bend and eventually break your internal cartridge guide. This printable model hopes to help with this issue by giving you a replacement.

There are one or two other replacement cart guides available from online sources, but only this version has been designed to be compatible with the most 2600 cartridges possible. So far, only certain Tigervision cartridges with long dust cover pins have been found to be incompatible, but this is an issue with the 7800 cart guide in general.

You'll want some decent infill to make sure the screw posts are nice and strong. You will also want to tweak retraction distance, otherwise the pins might not print fully. Cura's default setting proved to be too much. Using 4.5 millimeters and watching it carefully to make sure it feeds properly after each retraction seems to help. I will update this thing with pictures as soon as I print the latest version.

After Printing

Be very gentle when tearing out the supports. I recommend cutting the supports around the lock tabs at the bottom, otherwise you might break them. The tabs are not technically necessary since the guide is screwed into another part, but they provide some extra stability and are present on the original cartridge guide.

description.text:
This is an enlarged version of mtuieee's simple hook, redesigned to fit a countersunk 4.5 mm screw in the middle.

The hook's base is 38×38 mm and the hook is relatively strong if printed with >50% infill for the layers above 5mm (using PLA). Perfect for keys, clothing, lightweight bags (or heavier things if you go with 100% infill and/or stronger plastics, like ABS or Nylon).

description.text:
Remixed front-facing Z end-stop from RC-3D for the Tevo Tarantula.

The switch holder is exactly the same (included here for convenience).
The remixed screw-holder has the following changes compared to the original:

  • Uses two M3 20mm screws to hold onto the X carriage as opposed to 15mm only, allowing for a full 5mm base plate.
  • More tolerance on the M5 main adjustment screw. The screw still needs to be forced into the plastic carving it's own thread, but there's no need to heat the screw. The fit is still tight: the screw cannot be turned with bare hands.
  • The M5 screw is perfectly centered on the microswitch lever, not on the actuator. I recommend leaving the lever on the microswitch.

I cannot recommend the front-facing adjustment enough: given how often the bed needs to be re-leveled, this is easily the best mod I did on the Tarantula so far.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The arm attaching to the main M5 adjustment screw should have 100% infill. slic3r correctly fills small areas by default, so you can use 30% infill for the other parts. If you slicer doesn't do this, use 100% infill on the screw holder, and your favorite value on the switch holder.

title: Ultra Water Saving Device - Shower Flow Restrictor

description.text: I use one of these in both of my showers to conserver water.  I included a 0.5/0.75/1/1.5/2/2.5mm orifice water saver disc as different people have different wants and water pressure (mine is very high and I use the 0.75mm size where I get ~0.8gpm out of a 2.5gpm shower head.  The 2mm is about 1.5gpm and the 2.5mm is ~2-2.25gpm all at full force so you can turn down the faucets to lower it even more).

This is a simple item to make for a 3d Printer or 3 axis CNC.  While this is being made you need to remove your current shower head, and the old teflon tape over the threads.  Remove the washer from your shower head and pop in the disc you just made then put the washer back in over the disc.  Use your new teflon tape on the threads and replace your shower head that has now been transformed into an ultra water saving device.

author: DarkAlchemist

description.text:
So out of curiosity I bought the cheapest printer in ebay - here in Australia. IT's an ezt3d delta kossel. I won't bore you with the details, there are many shortcomings. But it does print exceptionally well for a delta! IT's just getting it to print that's a pain. The shipped controller board is a custom ezt3d STM32 controller, rather nice hardware specs, but the most awful firmware ever. And no usb port to upgrade!. Who builds a firmware that can't read more than 8 char of a filename, I've not seen that since the days of DOS. The straw that broke the camels back was that the heat bed get's disabled at about layer 20. And you can't control that. I had switched to a glass bed, because I got sick of gouging holes in the shipped build tack sticker, but with a glass bed the parts detach on about layer 30. So frustrating that you can't even disable the bed heater getting switched off. I gave up trying to reflash the unit using what I think is the diagnostic port, as it seems too hard to get a firmware stack setup to flash into it....

So - I'm upgrading it to a MKS Base Gen L. This unit seems to fit in place quite well, I did need to re route the extruder wires, but no big deal. most of the connectors plug in. But I did have to replace the main power leads and mod the heatbed connector. This needs to be done carefully as they are quite high current on this printer.

The base part simply sticks with hot melt glue to the acrylic base. Then the MKS base screws in with 3mm6mm hex bolts. The fan is a very cheap 80mm15mm fan, which is also exceptionally quiet. The fan assembly also hot melt glues onto the base.

I printed this using my trusty Tronxy X1, just used 0.2mm layer and I went for 60% infill, but should easily cope with 20%. Oh and those square tabs are simply to increase the adhesion at the corners so they don't lift. I print onto a frp board and unfortunately they stopped making the old uhu sticks. The new uhu sticks do not stick as well as the old, so I've taken to adding these extra tabs to corners. Just crack them off and all is good.. (or drill a hole and use them to mount instead of hot melt.)

Any way... If you have been frustrated by the piece of crap EZT3d printer here is a way forward! Oh and also before you switch that piece of crap on again replace that IEC connector with a proper 3 wire one with a fuse. The standard one is NOT EARTHED! And that power supply is probably shonky so I would not have it powered up without a proper earth.

Next upgrades for this printer - RepRap Full graphics display, then I might rebuild it with a full kossel stock frame, the acrylic is easy to break.

title: Tapadera para el contenedor de la sal de la cocina. (Cover for the container of the salt of the kitchen)

description.text:
.Me cansé de ver la tapadera rota de los tarros de plástico de la sal. Sale más barato comprar otros nuevos pero decidí hacerlos. Para diferenciarlos he hecho uno para la sal fina y cuando cambie el filamento haré el de la sal gorda.
Lo suyo habría sido hacerlo en flexible pero al hacer la prueba se me olvidó quitar la retracción, lo cual aconsejan, y casi cuando estaba acabando la primera capa, el material paró de salir, el filamento estaba liado en el motor del extrusor. Aunque no aconsejan utilizar el flexible con el extrusor tipo bowden, según consejo de CONTROL 3D, es mas fácil de desatascar en este tipo de extrusores. Efectivamente, apreté el clip del extrusor y al tirar del filamento este se desatascó facilmento y salio el filamento. Lo tengo que intentar de nuevo. El flexible que utilizo es el de SmartMaterials que tiene menos complicaciones que el de Recreus.
Es cuestión de seguir probando.

Traducción Google:
I got tired of seeing the broken lid of the plastic jars of salt. It is cheaper to buy new ones but I decided to make them. In order to differentiate them I have made one for the fine salt and when I change the filament I will make the salt one.
His would have been doing it in flexible but when doing the test I forgot to remove the retraction, which is advisable, and almost when I was finishing the first layer, the material stopped coming out, the filament was bundled in the extruder motor. Although they do not recommend using the flexible with the bowden extruder, according to the advice of CONTROL 3D, it is easier to unclog in this type of extruders. Sure enough, I pressed the clip of the extruder and when pulling the filament it unclogged easily and the filament came out. I have to try again. The flexible that I use is that of SmartMaterials that has fewer complications than Recreus.
It's a matter of continuing to try.

description.text:
I am stuck on crutches for 12 weeks which is rubbish. It has given me time to improve my 3D modelling and 3D printing though.

The standard issue UK crutches are not comfortable and dig in to the forearm. I designed these simple wrist guards to give more support to the forearm and wrist when walking around. They make it noticeably more comfortable.

Ideally the flat surface would be curved but that would also be a pig to print so it remains flat. I made it quite thin so it bends into a curve for greater comfort but with bracing on the back to stop it breaking. There are two holes in one of the support mounts in case you want to secure with wires - I never bothered and had no problems.

I have managed to break one when I dropped the crutch but they are easy enough to reprint.

Mine are printed in PETG as that is all I have but I am sure they would work in ABS or PLA too

description.text:
I printed the Ultra Small Pi Zero W Case (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2549847) and equipped it with a Raspberry Pi Zero W and the Pi Zero Camera. The idea was to set it up as an Octopi controller to monitor ongoing prints remote. I decided to make a frame with a GoPro type of mount in order to be flexible and to be able to use it for possible other applications (home automation, security etc.). Used the project to learn Fusion360 (fantastic, use YouTube for some good introductions). So all in all I used for this project:

  • Raspberry Pi Zero W
  • Pi Zero essentials Kit
  • Pi Zero Camera
  • Printed Pi Zero with Camera housing (thing:2549847)
  • The frame (OctoprintCamHolder v17.stl)
  • The mount on the Vertex K8400 frame (K8400GoproMount v3.stl)
  • Nut and Bold M5 18mm (The nut should fit in the mount)

To print both STL files I used Quality 0.2, Adhesion Brim and Infill Density 30 percent. Use supports everywhere.

Beethefirst internal spool holder attachment for Ziro 1kg spools. Uses existing stock magnetised spool pin and holder, which should click into place.

Was growing tired of replacing Beeverycreative's small and relatively expensive filaments. Furthermore, I wanted to keep the spool neat and internal. So, I designed this.

I have specifically specified Ziro spools as they have centre cutaway that fits nicely over the existing spool holder base. The design is quite tight and sits flush with the Ziro spool (54mm diameter with a 56mm lip) to ensure that the reel does not sag and touch the build plate at the start of the print.

You can see from the photos that the clearance from the base plate is tight (~0.75mm), but it should not touch the plate during printing.

Work in progress: Deleted V3 caused too much friction with the stock spool holder during use, which caused extrusion problems. Testing a new version (attached) with a looser grip with the stock spool pin to allow for freer movement.

description.text: LED Tardis charm with built in battery holder (takes two AG6 batteries) and sized for 3mm or 5mm LEDs. Has hole for 6mm jump ring or earring attachments. I am selling these on Etsy if anyone who doesn't have access to a 3D printer wants one: https://www.etsy.com/listing/184008967/glowing-led-tardis-charm New design holds the battery better without cracking like the prior version did, and allows easier replacement of the batteries.

Print the battery holder and either the 3mm or 5mm top depending on the size of your LED.  I use slow flashing/1Hz LEDs for the ones I make.  
Once printed, put the two AG6 batteries in the battery holder (facing the same way) and slide the legs of the LED into the slots in the battery holder, making sure to align the positive leg of the LED to the positive face of the battery.The legs of the LEDs should feed through the holes in the bottom of the base.  Once the LED is at the desired height, fold them over into the channels provided for them in the base.  I like to put a dab of superglue on them to make things more sturdy.  
If there is "extra" material inside the top near the opening, just scrape it out with a knife or pair of scissors.  
Slide the battery holder into the top section, making sure to line the sides where the batteries stick out with the grooves in the top section - no soldering necessary!  Friction will hold the bottom in place.

This is a remake, of Anet A8 Electronics Case by FqFKrazz. I was having a hard time finding a case that would fit on my printer bed so I took this one and cut it into three pieces so it would fit by bed. I like the way this case has the USB ports coming out the side and the fact that it fits around the Hulk frame braces. It also has room to hold everything I wanted to include on my build.

I put everything on my printer and it fits pretty well. I did have to drill a few holes through the case and frame for screws to attach it. I used some screws I had laying around to attach the MOSFETs and motherboard. The screw holes are pretty small and you may want to buy some smaller screws. M3 screws leftover from your build will work, but it’s a tight and forceful squeeze to get them to catch in the small holes.

author: jgerardo

description.text:
This is the complete set of Hills and Sheep, Printed on a single extruder printer, SPECIAL thanks for the collaboration from F1rst W0rd, Printing was the same as the base game, with painting Green for just the Hills and Vineyards and tops of Cloisters RED - because of the top blue wall color that is needed. If you think the flags on the hills are too fragile you can just snip it off before painting. In Game play there is no placing under of a second tile after drawing a hill tile... the only point of this was to elevate the hill tile...and with it being 3D printed the hill is of course elevated and clearly seen.

This is RIFRAF Carcassonne
Printed on a single extruder printer. Approx. same size tiles as original. No two tiles are alike, all custom made with a “c” inlay and 3d texture to the fields and city floor... There is very little to paint, I used 8 different colors of PLA filament and was very precise in my layering. You can see I had some stringing issues with some filament in the pictures, unfortunately the PLA was not the best quality.
Great thanks to all who went before with their developing this game and the many parts. There are dozens of “pieces” from others ideas assembled and added to here. Without the pioneers gone before us we would not be here today. Enjoy!
The compete Base set is finished here, see Rifraf Carcassonne…the River, Festivals, Inns & Cathedrals, Traders & Builders, Abbey & Mayor, The Princess & the Dragon, and The Tower in my other posts, Under the Big Top, over 240 Tiles total.
The Original Set: 72 Tiles
The River: 12 Tiles
Festivals: 10 Tiles
Inns & Cathedrals: 18 Tiles
Traders & Builders: 24 Tiles
Abbey & Mayor: 18 Tiles
The Princess & the Dragon: 30 Tiles
The Tower: 18 Tiles
Under the Big Top: 20 Game Tiles
Hills and Sheep: 18 Tiles
How I printed: On a Prusa i3 MK2 in all PLA with a base height of .200mm and a layer height of .150 with a 4mm nozzle. 4 Base layers and 3 top layers, 15% Cubic infill with a CONCENTRIC Top/Bottom fill pattern, This is important if you want the same layer divisions and “style”. I printed with a 3mm brim attached to all tiles, I found if I did not I got the occasional corner lift, but it did mean I had to trim the sides of all the tiles.
What I painted: The tops of the farm and city houses..RED, the 6 Volcano and 6 “portal” tiles from The Princess and the Dragon…GREY, and the filled in the garden squares using a toothpick and 4 different paints for the flowers…and the tops of the festival tents…That’s it…(there are 2 tiles in The Princess & Dragon that have the cloisters AND emblems, you will have to decide between painting the cloister or wall top towers)..that is if you print the way I did.
Some issues and tips: This is very important…When slicing in Slic3r sometimes the tiles would not render with the correct number of top layers, for example the roads would only have a layer or two finished and then the fill would show through…or the fields would not have all the layers… for some reason, rotating the affected tile 90 degrees on the plate sometimes a couple times and then reslicing fixed this issue…do a good preview check to examine how your layers are printing… it was a ton of wasted prints for me to work this out.
The very base layer has the “C” cut out, if you make your base layer one color, then change to a different color for the next few layers the filament with just “flow” into this space and it looks like you have a nice inlay…it does not affect the rest of the printing in any way… this is the “poor man’s inlay trick”…also the concentric fill pattern on the bottom gives it the “scattered” look sort of like the original tiles.
The fields have a darker layer under the light green, this adds to the textured look, also the City floor has a Dark brown layer followed by two copper layers for the “cobble stone” look, you can experiment with different color materials for enhance the “3d” look of these areas.
I have not printed all the Princess & the Dragon, Under the Big Top, Traders & Builders…or Hills and Sheep, I ran out of filament... .. they look good but if they are anything like the rest of the tiles I will have to go back to correct an item or two.. Please let me know.
The Towers are designed to fit snug.
My Printing and colors: (How you slice will of course change any of these) I used Prusa Color print to define the layers.
For all tiles except the ones with a Cloister, the Cathedrals, and the Abbeys
0-.35 Light Green (The Base color, will be shaded according to the subsequent layers)
.35-1.1 Blue (For the base of the ponds)

description.text:
Hey makers !

Here you have the result of some hard work of one of my favorite videogames !
Every character of Binding Of Isaac is here, if its own item.

I hope you'll like it, post your made one :)

If you don't have any 3D printer, you can buy me some on my Etsy shop:
http://etsy.me/2p6qrGL

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10-15

Notes:

Most parts can be printed without any supports. It includes objects, heads and bodies.

Some hair parts can be printed upside down to avoid using supports, but unfortunately i could'nt do this for all of them.

So you will need to enable supports for these parts:

Eve Hair
Eden Hair 1
Lazarus Hair

Everything else is fine !

Assembling

When modeling all these little buddies, I did my possible to make most parts standard.

There are anyway a lot of files! That's why you can refer to the image under this text block.

Be sure to use head without eyebrows for Samson and Lilith or their hair won't fit in !

How to build these little buddies? Painting

I know that everyone has its own technique for painting, and it's not my best quality.
Anyway, I share mine with you, maybe it can help !

I personnaly use Piglet Pink aerosol from the Molotow series as a base for skin-color parts, and then paint on it when dry with a pastel skin marker from the same brand.
Even if it's not perfectly painted, it's still good with the aerosol base under it.

Most characters parts can be painted easily, so you can do it even if you're a noobie like me :p

Acrylic paint for skin parts

Modeling

I use Sketchup for almost ten years and, as a professionnel 3D printer/modeler, I use it every day of the week !
Some can say that's not the best software to do it, but hey, I don't care !

I modeled every character and most items from scratch, using sprites found on the internet as reference. It took me a looooooooooooot of time, but now I'm pretty satisfied of the result :)

Little story to tell about the Appollyon model:
I started from a sprite found on the internet to model it, and when everything was printed and finished, I noticed that he was different from the character in the game.
In fact, it was different because I used an old sprite before the character release.
So I re-modeled Appollyon but conserved the old one because I like it too !

I wanted to use my terrible 3d skills to create a plaque to remember my Philadelphia Eagles SUPERBOWL WIN!

So i sat down and started designing it. I ended up going with 290mm diameter circle and I designed/laid all this out in tinkercad. The base plate is 1.5mm tall. The green layer is 1mm high, then the black layer is 1mm high, followed by 1mm grey, 1mm white and 1 final 1.5mm grey on top. It allowed me to get the words in green and the philly special play! and the complete colored eagles logo.

I printed it on my trusty CR-10s that I love and its 300x300x400mm build area. I used S3D so I used the tool slice each layer where i do color change into saved gcode and then print them 1 at a time on top of each other.

Total print time: 9 hours
Estimated material cost: $2.50
Total Weight: 153g

I've uploaded .gcode files I created as well to make it super easy to print different colors. Just load up one at a time. start with 1 end with 6.

layer 1: white
layer 2: midnight green
layer 3: black
layer 4: grey/silver
layer 5: white
layer 6: grey/silver

Enjoy and please give me any feedback!

description.text: This is a chopper wheel for optical and optoelectronic experiments. This component is part of the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware: by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

Use the OpenSCAD files to customize it for your application, print on your favorite open source 3-D printer and enjoy. It is only one number that controls the number of slots. 4, 10 and 14 slot stl files are shown as examples and should cover from low frequency to about 1400 Hz. You can of course go higher if you need to. Included are the code for wheels with a nut cage for mounting firmly to a spinning shaft. Full information here on Appropedia Thanks to Nick for the code. This component is part of the Open-source Optics Library: Zhang C, Anzalone NC, Faria RP, Pearce JM (2013) Open-Source 3D-Printable Optics Equipment. PLoS ONE 8(3): e59840. This is part of a larger project to reduce the cost of scientific equipment using open-source hardware. Read more here

title: Redcat Everest Gen7 Trimmed Chassis Mount Servo CMS Plate

description.text:
Remix of design by Redcat.

Trimmed CMS plate to allow more movement of the axle. The original CMS reduces compression by a few MM due to the axle truss hitting the panhard mount.

Rear panhard mount was removed and large chunk of the middle portion as well. This allows the truss to just barely fit inside the CMS. Meaning you get more downward compression of the suspension.

Suggest using PETG or ABS but PLA with a high infill or annealed may be sufficient.

title: Bowden Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a quite simple bowden extruder, albeit for a very specific mounting case. I couldn't find a ready-to-use solution so I designed this one from scratch.

My 3D printer is placed in an Ikea housing (Stuva box with glass door) on which I have several of my filament dispenser boxes (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2754979). The filament ix fed through the top into the direct drive extruder. This is working fine but I always wanted to try a bowden extruder, just to get familiar with it. This extruder is specifically designed to be mounted on top of the housing, as shown in the images.

Update

I added a bowden extruder body for the original Prusa i3 MK2/S. It's basically the original part with the motor mount trimmed away. I also added an additional hex nut to keep the top mounting spot (the second one I added was a mistake, ignore it ;-) ).

Since the extruder uses a different drive gear I had to recalibrate the steps/mm for the extruder motor. You can do this with the M503, M92 and M500 commands. There's some excellent documentation on the Marlin website. For the Prusa i3 I adjusted the extrusion from 161.3 steps/mm to 142.1 steps/mm.

Furthermore I modified the retraction settings in the Slic3r settings to 5 mm retraction length and 100 mm/s retraction speed. This just a start though and will probably be refined later on.

The first print is shown in the images above. I really did not expect it to work so well right out of the box. It still needs some fine tuning though. It appears there's some over-extrusion and the bed height offset is not quite right.
Another issue I noticed is the extruder motor skipping some steps on high load situations. I used a different motor with higher torque, so maybe the current settings are inappropriate. I probably will just switch to the original Prusa motor.

Other than that it works suprisingly well. :-)

ChangeLog

  • 2018-03-10
    Original Prusa motor and drive gear mounted. No more stalls or skipped steps, works fine. Fine-tuning of Slic3r can begin...

  • 2018-03-03
    Extruder assembled and tested.

  • 2018-03-02:
    Original upload

Parts list

The extruder uses/requires the following parts:

  • 1 E3D Hobb-Goblin 5mm drive gear
  • 1 E3D groove mount bowden adaptor
  • 1 quick connector for Teflon tube

  • 1 push fit M5 thread

  • 1 625 ball bearing

  • 1 5x14 mm cylinder rod

  • 2 M6x40 screws
  • 5 M3x35 screws
  • 1 M3x40 screw (+ spring and washers)
  • 2 hex nuts M6
  • 1 hex nut M3
  • 1 square nut M3

description.text:
PLEASE NOTE - I'M NOT RESPONSABLE FOR ANY DAMAGE CAUSED BY MY DESIGN.

I designed this holder to hold my dial indicator in place for bed leveling. Originally I planned to add some sort of clamp. But it has a pretty tight fit.

It was designed to hold an 8mm Shaft (designed radius 4,1 mm). Now it's press fitted and that's fine for my usecase.
My printout was a bit too tight in the carriage. So I had to grind and cut it a little bit. I modified the file accordingly but did not try a new print. Please let me know how it fits.

I added the FreeCAD file for customization and modification. Please note that I'm by far no FreeCAD expert I experiented some trouble during corner smoothing. Feel free to adjust it to your needs.

It turns out that the dial probe does not reach the front and does overshoot the back of the bed a little bit. I recommend to install the dial facing to the opposite side (compared to the pic). This way you will shift the usable range approximately 1cm towards the front of the bed.

title: Side Trough for Tevo Tornado and Creality CR-10

description.text:
This Trough fits on the right side of printer, as a catch for sweeping debris off. Helps to keep your work area clean.

Fits a Tevo Tornado, and should fit a Creality CR-10 (please let me know CR-10 users).

The sidewalls are thin to save on Fillament, but print cleanly. This is my 3rd revision of it having printed thiner, thicker, etc.. The provided model is "Just Right".

The .gcode file is generated on Slic3r for a Tevo Tornado, but should print and also fit the Creality CR-10 (again let me know). It's set for 0.1 layer height, 50 degree bed, and 200 degree hot end. Has both rafting and supports in the gcode.

The OpenSCAD files are also provided if you want to modify it. If you do, please upload a "Remix".
Designed in OpenSCAD, and the file is a part of the files package. Can be easily edited by anyone and dimensions changed easily by editing the variables.

Works perfect for training with your gun, disables it and you can see its safe also it can be dry fired without damaging the firing pin.

Original Car Design by lio dub.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078194
https://www.thingiverse.com/lio_/about
Kudos to him for a very nice car model.

This is a Redux of his cars and my messing around with ideas that I had.

It Uses an Arduino nano for driving the system. Note that I don't offer support in programming and using an Arduino.

https://www.amazon.com/
Search for Arduino Nano

It uses steppers. Why?? Because they are easy, have torque and are speed and direction manageable.

The steppers. You get 1 and 3 spare. (More things to build!)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01CP18J4A/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The code below uses the AccelStepper library for Arduino.
http://www.airspayce.com/mikem/arduino/AccelStepper/

The string is a nylon type of sewing craft thread. It does not get hairs or stretch. Basically string cable. The Car cable carriers print with a slit to run the string through. After tying the cable taught, slip the string in the carrier and use a dab ( very small amount )of superglue. You don't need the cable super tight, but tight enough for the drive wheels to keep friction. Was thinking of metal bead cable and lighting the cars with the power.

You may code your steppers however you wish, it is just the basic program that sets speed and direction. However; with the Nano you can address the inputs. I plan on using either optical or magnetic sensors to slow down for unload. Then go, with random reversing.

At Christmas I had it going from the Mountain station on the mantle next to the Xmas Tree to a top ski lodge across the room.

Here is code that will get you going. It just runs for some time, and then slows down, stops and reverses.

include

define HALFSTEP 8

define motorPin1 3

define motorPin2 4

define motorPin3 5

define motorPin4 6

AccelStepper stepper1(HALFSTEP, motorPin1, motorPin3, motorPin2, motorPin4);

void setup() {
// setup code

stepper1.setMaxSpeed(1000.0);
stepper1.setAcceleration(100.0);
stepper1.setSpeed(200);
stepper1.moveTo(20000);

}

void loop() {
// run repeatedly

if (stepper1.distanceToGo() ==0) {
delay(500);

stepper1.moveTo(-stepper1.currentPosition());
}
stepper1.run();
}

Have fun, print and build!

title: Kingdom Death Monster Gear Grid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my gear grid for KDM 1.5 which i find quite convenient. It implements enough space for all gear cards which fit even sleeved. Additionally it nullifies any record keeping on your survivor sheet for armor values. Just turn the dice to your desired value. Light and Heavy injuries can be recorded via the token you place on top of the hit locations. Bleeding is added as well and a slot for status cards of some enemies.

The board comes in 2 variants. One with 3mm holes in the side for magnets. Currently i'm designing a board for survivor sheets and the magnets will be for snapping them together.
The other variant is without the holes if you won't need the survivor board.

I hope you enjoy them while suffering eternally playing this awesome game. I recommend using the survivor sheets by my buddy Dagrimone (the sheets without Armor values) for maximum efficiency:
https://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/158463/variant-survivor-sheets-official-campaigns-half-le

comments.text: These look awesome!
comments.author: Fenlon

comments.text: You can use Tinkercad. It's free and easy  to use. Just edit the stl,   define a cylinder as a "hole" and with  a diameter  of  your capsules  and cut it out.
comments.author: Fenlon

comments.text: Holy exploding heads, this is amazing.  One question - how do the L/H bits work?  It looks like there is a little insert for each hit location, and then a separate marker for Light and one for Heavy?  So for one survivor board, you'd need 5 inserts and 10 total markers?  Or am I totally misunderstanding.
comments.author: thedodus

comments.text: I printed 20 L-wound marker and 20 H-wound marker in total. You would rarely need that many but it is the maximum possible (5 L and 5 H for each survivor). The base of the markers are U-Shaped and fit tightly into square of the hit location as shown in one of the pictures. For example if any survivor suffers a light wound in the Arms you just take one token and place it either at the top or the bottom of the Arms symbol. Up to you. If the survivors suffers an additional wound in the arms you can just take the H-wound token and place in the free space or replace the L-Token. Again it's up to you :-)  The "insert" is definitly not necessary for the board. I just added it for storage because i designed it anyways. In my case i glued it into the dicecase for each survivor. I'll attach a  picture. You could store all 20 Tokens in the box or print out 4 for each survivor.

title: Pitan body for metal bowden fitting

description.text:
I created this remix in order to be able to use a metal bowden fitting with 1/8 NPT thread instead of the plastic insert. The thread in the body is not "real" NPT, but a custom metric thread around 9.7mm (I found M10 thread to be too loose).
The "spacer" (or disc) is needed between the back part of the metal fitting and the filament guide in order to avoid a gap of approx 3.5 mm between the fitting and the filament guide.

Additionally, I had to reduce the internal diameter of the small gear (from 5.2mm to 5.1mm), as it was too loose on my stepper motor.

title: Key Fob - Cover or Keychain Repair

description.text:
One of my friends had asked me to 3D print something that would allow him to fix his broken GYM Access Key Fob. These are the types of fobs used for Door Access Control in office building, apartments, schools, and home security. Apparently, the keychain cutout in the normal HID Key Fobs is prone to breakage after heavy use. To make matters worse some companies are charging users a lot of money to replace damaged or lost Key Fobs. Making this quick and cheap solution even more appealing.

Thinking about the problem at hand the best solution appeared to be a case that could fit around the fob and give it a new & stronger keychain loop. As I always try to do in my designs, I used several different Fobs I had collected in order to make this a universal fit. The case bottom and top just snap together around your fob to give it some extra strength and protection. There is also a small notch cut into the top section to allow it to be separated by either a coin or key, if you need to retrieve the fob on the go.

This turned out so good that I have used it on my company keyfob just to protect it from breaking the future.

Hope you guys enjoy.

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Wall Mount for Security Camera

description.text:
This is a security camera using the Raspberry Pi Zero and the NoIR camera module. The wall mount was an adaptation of yyh1002's modular mounting system: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194278.
The raspberry pi case was modified from Superrei's Raspberry pi case: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1595429.

I have summarised the way to make the security camera using motioneye.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I used the same settings as outlined in each of the builds.

Making the security camera

Download the latest Motioneye OS from https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki/Installation.

Once the microSD has been formatted and the OS written to the card make sure you add the txt file which will tell the raspberry pi about your wifi connectivity. Instructions on how: https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki/Wifi-Preconfiguration

Then plug in the camera and the power and should be good to go. You need to find the IP address of the camera which can be found if you go to your router settings. (It can be fixed later once you set up the camera settings). Type in that IP address into the web browser and you should be able to tinker with settings. That wiki link will tell you what each setting does.

I've also ftp linked it to my QNAP NAS to store the data. That way if the camera is unplugged or taken I still have access to the images/videos.
