author: lolodyn

title: Prusa i3 MK3 Mean Well PSU Case and Mounting Bracket

description.text:
What is it?

Since power supplies for the Prusa i3 mk3 seem to be unreliable, I designed a PSU cover so you can use a Mean Well NES-350-24 or it's replacement the LRS-350-24. The only difference between the two is that the LRS-350 is a thinner 1U form factor. The cover was designed to keep the same sleek look as the stock PSU. Any feedback is welcome.

Hardware

You can use the stock screws and nuts for the bottom PSU cover plate. Those are M3X8
6 M4X10 flat head screws
2 M4X12R to mount the PSU to the Prusa frame.
2 M4 Nuts up to 3mm thick

IMPORTANT: The screws that attach the PSU to the Prusa frame must not be too long. If they are, they will press up against the power supply and warp the frame. Only tighten these enough to make the PSU snug.

Notes:

  1. The Mean Well PSUs mount with M4 hardware. I chose countersunk screws
  2. You will need two M4 Thin nuts to mount the adapter plate to the Prusa Frame. You will also need longer screws to mount the plate to the frame.
  3. I had to notch out a small area on the PSU bottom plate to make clearance for the rear extrusion frame. This 6.5mmX 6.5mm area may need minimal supports. Feedback on this is welcome.
  4. I have not tested the LRS-350 Version because I do not have this PSU, but luckily Mean Well provide schematics for their PSUs. Let me know if I need to make a change.

print_settings.Resolution:: What ever you want to try

description.text:
Yes, I also got bored of wasting filament in useless cubes.

This is a simple 20x20mm cube with proper dice dots. And, by proper, I mean all opposite dice faces sum 7....
Dots are 4mm diameter and 2mm depth. "Letters" lines are 1x1mm So you can also test your printer accuracy.

Just for the record, remember the calibration formula:

(desired size/obtained size)*current number of steps per mm = new needed number of steps per mm.

In most printers, you can set this number on screen (remember to save it to the eeprom). In others, you can use Gcode G92 like this: G92 Xstepsxmm Zstepsxmm Ystepsxmm.
You can see your current G92 settings using Gcode code M503 and store settings with code M500.

author: sebballl

title: C60 Burning Man Art Piece Model

description.text:
This is a teeny tiny version of a Burning Man art piece named C60. It is meant to be a representation of a Buckminsterfullerene, a molecular structure with sixty carbon atoms, which is where the name comes from. It was built by the group, “Thanks, Bourbon,” and the full piece was made from steal, wreathed in flames, and four feet in diameter. This 3D printable version was designed as a reward for kickstarter backers. The Kickstarter is now closed, but head there if you want to learn more about the piece.

If you were one of our backers, FREAKIN THANK YOU! You are the best! And we couldn’t have built such an awesome piece without you.

Love,
Thanks, Bourbon

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/thanksbourbon/c60-burning-man-2017?ref=user_menu

Assembly Instructions
• You will need to print 20 panels to create a full structure
• It’s recommended that you print panels with no support material or rafts
• It’s easiest to assemble a 5 piece “flower” and then build from there
• The the most important thing to keep in mind is that every opening is created by 5 interlocking panels. It is fairly easy to accidentally make one with 4 pieces
• One you have 15 panels connected, it’s easiest to make another 5 piece “flower” with the last 5 panels, and then attach them all at once
• The process is somewhat finicky and you will need to bend some panels. But you can do it!

title: Filter Box Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Need to filter dust and hair out of the air for something? Make a filter box out of ... filters. I have a couple of antminers. They suck a lot of air in to cool the chips. But that air contains dust and hair that can get caught on heatsinks and gum up the airflow. Putting a piece of filter material on the inlet works, but restricts the airflow more than I wanted. I considered building a chute that I could attach a furnace filter to, but then came up with a simpler and better idea: make a filter box out of the filters themselves. All I needed was a bracket that would hold the edges together. This design seems to work pretty well, with a caveat: there will still be a small gap along the edges, allowing some air to bypass the filters. But it's simple and cheap. If you want a slightly firmer grip, adjust the size of the bracket. They are designed to work with standard 1" furnace filters.

These mods add trigger, hammer, and bolt functionality, as well as the ability to disassemble the blaster as needed.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3AlSItja6sI

01_Barrel - Added hole for bolt spring screw (M3x18mm)

11_GripPin - Modified length to correct length
15_TriggerMechanismA - Narrowed part to facilitate barrel sliding over it to lock it down
16_TriggerMechanismB - Narrowed part to facilitate barrel sliding over it to lock it down

Hardware list:

  4. Thumbscrew nuts (8-32 (x3))

description.text:
These parts are to replace Hairygael's InMoov original thumb's base.
It gives more DOF by allowing the thumb's angle to be adjusted.
It uses the same wiring principle as for the fingers, and the knots will be hidden after gluing the tip part. Updated 08/08/2012 : uploaded the parts for the right thumb Updated 28/08/2012 : I made a new version of the base that is more respectful with the original InMoov's thumb angle. It's also stronger. Please read instructions. Updated 16/11/2013 : after Balse's constructive comment (thanks!) I have corrected a few small problems. Only the right thumb is available ATM but I will also upload the left thumb soon. Updated 24/01/2014 : I uploaded the new base that user Balse modified (left and right). Please read his comments to know why he made that correction. Thanks Balse ! For more information please visit http://www.reppersdelight.spacymen.com/index.php/post/2012/08/08/Thumb-UP!

• Print using ABS and a 30% infill and supports set at 10-20 degrees.
  • After removing supports, fix the 2 biggest parts together with an M3 20mm bolt as axe.
  • Put 1 wire into each hole and make a knot on each
  • You can now glue the last part and it will hide the knots (you can use acetone for gluing).
  • take away the original thumb, remove the base part and fix it back to the new base.
  • put the 4 thumb's wires in place
    • Left version :
    just print the left version of the base (balse version) and reprint the other two parts

title: Anet A8 cable strain relief
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE / V2
Revisited the design, V2 is smaller, lighter... faster print (1h30m), less filament (13gr), more elegant, and also keeps the back springs tight and straight. Push the springs down the shaft and mount it under the bed. The flat part has to face up. Use a ziptie to fasten the cable to the strain relief. I must say, the result is also pretty rigid, much more than you would assume. Printed this with 3 walls (1.2mm) and 15% infill (grid).
I also added a design for the front spring caps, for the two front corners, so you can bring the bed down to the same height. You can also put the springs inside to keep leveling the bed with the bedscrews or bedlevel knobs, while keeping them straight. I also designed the bedlevel wingnut knobs, for those interested.
Kudos to JAWehrung who designed thing:1895223, it was what inspired me to make the strainrelief this way. Although i didn't remix his model.

ORIGINAL INFO / V1
I needed a strainrelief, and since i didn't want to dismantle the entire bed (bed + carriage from the bearing blocks) to install one of the existing strain relief designs, i designed a new one.

I wanted it to be:

  • an easy print (no supports or overhangs etc)
  • a relatively fast print (at about 2.5 hours)
  • an easy install (no need to dismantle the bed)

I'm very aware this is not the most elegant solution, i didn't work on this for very long, but it works, and you only need to remove the back two screws from the bed in order to install it. So installation should be much faster and simpler than with most other A8 strain reliefs. The 8 holes are meant for zip ties, so you can route your cable as you see fit (depending on your setup). Print time should average around 2h30m with roughly 30gr of filament needed. No supports needed, just print it flat on the bed. Depending on your bed adhesion, you might want to consider printing a brim, since flat/long designs are prone to curl if your adhesion isn't that good. Use 0.2 mm layer height and 2 walls with a 10-15% infill. The design easily fits an A8 bed (see picture). Best printed with ABS if you intend to heat your bed higher than PLA temperatures (+/-50°).

The design is made to screw the bed all the way down, to ensure it stays snug and won't slant or sag. If you don't wish to screw your bed all the way down, there are holes for extra springs, to keep the strain relief lifted and keep it from sagging in the middle. These extra springs are not needed if you screw the bed down as intended, and compress the corner springs all the way.

title: Tronxy X1 simple 8mm Z screw adapter

description.text:
The stock 5mm lead screw on my Tronxy X1 came bent. Standard 8mm lead screws are both cheaper and easier to find, so I decided to convert it. This adapter holds the new 8mm lead nut. All the hardware was reused from the Tronxy kit. The new nut attaches to the bottom of the adapter with original screws as shown in the picture. The screws that go through the Z bracket into the adapter are NOT meant to be threaded into the adapter, they act like pins just to keep the adapter from rotating. The stock screw hole in the Z bracket is just barely big enough for the larger screw. Mine does not rub, but if yours does, simply file the hole a little bigger. You may also have to file down the heads of the Z bracket screws a little to keep them from rubbing on the new screw, I had to do it with one out of the three screws.

You will need to reset the Z steps in your firmware for the new screw. Using a 4 start, 2mm pitch 8mm lead screw, use 400 steps/mm.

Other things you will need for this conversion:
An 8mm x 250mm lead screw and nut
A 5mm x 8mm shaft coupler to go from the motor to the new screw.

I was working on something like a "walking machnie" based on the mechanism of Theo Jansens "strandbeest". The parts of both - Prototype I and Prototype II - work fine but I had troubles finding a suitable connection for the joints, since some of them require to be rotatable whilst others need to be locked. Further it was difficult preventing the screw-heads from getting in the way of each another. Therefore I built the third Prototype of this out of 3d-printed elements that had cavities for the heads of the screws (have a looka t my other projects, I uploaded this as a separate thingy).

For both prototypes I uploaded the blueprint that I lasercut in plexiglass. The joints I build with m4-screws and aluminum sticks. Since "Prototype I" was just a very rough model I used the cardboard box of a 10-pack as a chassis.
This project is not finished yet, if you want to work on it this interactive animation of the mechanism might be helpful to you:
http://www.mekanizmalar.com/theo_jansen.html

This is a maker coin, an item designed to be able to test the capabilities of a 3D Printer.
The coin is 1.5cm in width and 6cm in diameter.
It's loosely based on the Mayan calendar (so it looks more like a monkey than what it's supposed to) and has my last name featured at the top.
Very loosely based on this image

I created this Makercoin for a school project. I designed it so it would look like an aperture, with some smaller detailed cuts in the middle. It has six "blades", each with two full cuts through it. Through the middle of all of the cuts is a ring, concentric with the coin as a whole. There are smaller cuts near the center, which help to test the ability of the printer to print small details. The final product printed nicely with no supports needed, so it is also able to test bridging, to a small degree.

Enjoy!

title: Simchair MKIII cessna 182 engine & prop controls

description.text:
These are Cessna 182 style engine and prop controls. Good for flying any single engine piston powered plane though. This thing is very easy to make: Just print everything, add 3 slider pots, wire them to an RJ45 socket and plug it into a COL slot of Simchair MKIII controller (or use your own controller). As this is unlikely to be used for RC flying, and due to knobs placement in a real 182, this is intended to be mounted on the desk.

You will need:

6 x M3x25mm screws and 2 M3 nuts
3 x SL-4515G slider potentiometers or similar ones
(https://static.chipdip.ru/lib/996/DOC000996699.pdf)
red, blue and black nail polish (optional)
1 x 8p8c socket
1 x regular Ethernet cable (if used with simchair MKIII controller)
superglue (a drop put under a potentiometer will fix it in place)
Simchair MKIII controller (or another controller)

Standard connection method

Use the T-568B standard wire order for all your connections (see picture below).
Wires should be connected as follows:

white-orange 5v
orange GND
white-green Rx
blue Ry
white-blue Rz

description.text:
Print four of these and place one in each corner of the machine to increase the lid height by 100mm. This stops the plastic filament tube rubbing the inside of the lid and prevents scratching. Plus I don't have to prop the lid up or put it on my floor when not in use. Fit on the machine side is snug by design - mine needed a firm push to seat. The flat base should touch the upper face of the machine and the lip will clear by 1mm. I also added a blob of hot glue to make sure they don't move. Fit on the lid side is very loose so it's easy to fit the cover.

Recesses in the printed parts mean you can add sheet material to make a complete enclosure if you want to run ABS, etc. Most sheet material would probably work as long as it's under 4.65mm thick. Exact measurements (you decide on tolerance) for the side panels are:

  • 2 off @ 576.7mm wide x 105mm high
  • 2 off @ 544.7mm wide x 105mm high

author: WalkingDED

description.text: Remix for Tronxy x5s

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2-0,25

Infill:

25

Planes in the Set

  • P-38 Lightning
  • F4F Wildcat
  • A6M5 "Zeke" (aka late War Zero)
  • N1K2 "George"
  • Focke Wulf 190 A-series

1/144th scale fighter planes from World War Two. I modified the Lightning and Zero to remove the propellers, so that the props look like they're flying, for use in miniature wargaming. I scaled the Focke Wulf 190 A. These are all low-poly models.

I designed the N1K2 "George" and the F4F Wildcat using schematic drawings from the Rand McNally Color Illustrated Guide to World War II Airplanes. I then scaled the model to 1/144th scale based on the stated length in the book. I'm still learning how to use Blender, so these models are a little rough.

If you have any requests for World War Two aircraft, let me know. I have reference schematics for almost every plane from the War.

Tip me with Bitcoin at the address below:
14U3VBvFWYwz5A6Rtox2PiWDfZFLFJpFtZ

For the Japanese "George" aircraft, I first used a scanner to scan the schematic illustrations of the plane. Then I used GIMP (https://www.gimp.org/) to edit the scanned images to enhance the contrast and to trim the scanned page down to just the schematic drawing. See the image below.

Next, I opened Blender (https://www.blender.org/) to a clean work space. I added the schematic image as a background image three times ('N' to open the options panel, and then "Add Background Image"). I added one image in side view, one in top view, and one in front view, to match the perspectives from the schematic.

To see the image, you need to enter orthographic perspective ('5' on the numpad). I switched to side view ('3' on the numpad). Then I added a plane (not the flying kind...) to the workspace, rotated it 90 degrees around the Y-axis so it was visible. Then I dragged the vertices of the plane to match the silhouette of the "George," extruding extensions to the plane by selecting two vertices at a time.

After filling out the shape of the fuselage, I extruded the plane, switched to "Object" mode, added a mirror modifier, and started working from the other views (i.e. top and front). I extruded additional sections for the tail and wings.

I didn't worry about the scale of the model till the end. At the end, I looked up in my reference book for the length of the aircraft (30 feet, 8 inches). I converted to inches (368 inches), then converted to millimeters (by multiplying by 25.4 millimeters to the inch: 9,144mm), then divided by 144 to get the Y-dimension for the aircraft at 1/144th scale (63.5mm).

description.text:
This is a complete Electronics Housing for the F450 Type Quadcopter found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1206960

In this case you can Store PDB and Flight Controller with 30.5mm Spacing like Pixhawk Mini or any standard INAV Capable F3, F4 or F7 Flight controller. It has also enough room to put an 30.5mm Receiver Module on the same stack. In the Cover part, there are also Mounts for an 3DR Radio and an Eachine TX526 Video Transmitter. The telemetry module can be mounted with a small cable tie and the video transmitter will hold itself with the plug or can be additionally glued in. The VTx channel display and control button are accessible from top. The GPS Mount is hollow to hide the cables inside. The VTx needs an Extension cable to mount the antenna on the side of the housing.

ATTENTION: When using an FC with integrated Magnetometer, DO NOT put the PDB inside the housing, because it will distort the compass. When using an GPS with Magnetometer, this is no problem.

The cover is screwed down with 2 short M3 screws and also the GPS Mount is screwed on the cover with M3 screws. Just screw down the base with one screw of each leg.

The small 2mm holes on each side of the cover are preparation for 2.4GHz receiver antenna cables.

Any suggestions? Just leave a comment.

Links for fitting electronics:
3DR Telemetry (433MHz): https://www.banggood.com/3DR-Radio-Telemetry-433MHZ-Module-For-APM-APM2-Europe-p-85233.html
3DR Telemetry (915MHz): https://www.banggood.com/3DR-Radio-Telemetry-915MHZ-Module-For-APM-APM2-p-73539.html
VTx: https://www.banggood.com/Eachine-TX526-5_8G-40CH-25MW200MW600MW-Switchable-AV-Wireless-FPV-Transmitter-RP-SMA-Female-p-1083642.html
VTx Extension Cable: https://www.banggood.com/GEPRC-100mm-Low-Loss-Antenna-Extension-Cord-Wire-Fixed-Base-for-FPV-Multicopters-SMARP-SMA-p-1181450.html
VTx Antenna: https://www.banggood.com/Realacc-Pagoda-Antenna-RHCP-Right-Angle-5_8G-5dBi-50W-Omnidirectional-Omni-FPV-Antenna-SMARP-SMA-p-1219943.html
Receiver: https://www.banggood.com/Flysky-X6B-2_4G-6CH-i-BUS-PPM-PWM-Receiver-for-AFHDS-i6s-i6-i6x-Transmitter-p-1101513.html
GPS (with MAG): https://www.banggood.com/Ublox-NEO-M8N-Flight-Controller-GPS-with-Protective-Shell-for-PIX-PX4-Pixhawk-p-1005394.html

Our toilet flusher broke beyond repair, so I whipped this up as a fun fix for the kids. This is V1; updates to the design may happen in the future. At the time of posting this, it has been in fully functional use for 2 weeks with no problems.

I'm not sure if this is technically a remix, but I took the Flexy-Rex and removed everything but the head. You can find the original file here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738211

Since this is the first toilet handle I've fixed, I can't say if it'll work in your toilet or not. If you decide to try this, know that the hexagon joint is a VERY tight fit. I had to use a "C" clamp to install it. This effectively makes the installation permanent. I used fishing line to connect the chain to the new arm, as it didn't quite reach.

I printed the handle @ 50% infill; the arm @ 80% infill.

The handle .stl doesn't have perfect geometry, but Cura slices fine and it prints perfectly. You won't see the error after printing as it is on the backside. I'll fix this and other issues in the V2.

If you use this, please let me know!
